conclusion: Determining the Temperature at State B for an Ideal Gas
Analyzing the p-V diagram showing the states A, B, and C of the ideal gas
State A: Temperature T₁ = 27°C = 300 K (converting to Kelvin)
The p-V diagram shows the pressure (p) in units of 10⁵ Pa and the volume (V) in units of 10⁻³ m³
Extract coordinates from the p-V diagram: State A: (7, 1), State B: (7, 2), State C: (3, 3)
For an ideal gas, PV = nRT where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles (constant), R is the ideal gas constant, T is temperature in Kelvin
For a fixed amount of gas (constant n), P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂ = nR (constant)
Substituting the values: P₁ = 1 × 10⁵ Pa, V₁ = 7 × 10⁻³ m³, T₁ = 300 K, P₂ = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V₂ = 7 × 10⁻³ m³
The temperature of the gas in state B is 600 K or approximately 327°C
